@JT_Karaoke I've been watching Madmen lately and what confuses me is the things that are clearly authentic to the '60s (like I checked with my mom) versus '00s commentary on them. Because the '00s were kind of a while ago now, right? It's interesting.
@JT_Karaoke Watching an episode of Married with Children in 2022 has to feel like watching Madmen did in 2009. "Where things really like this?" Yes.

American Sci-fi movies between '77 and '87 are the exact opposite of French new wave movies and the New Hollywood movies they inspired. They are the antithesis. What this Disney drone is saying is fucking nonsense.

You know what American movies were inspired by French new wave films? '70s New Hollywood. The Conversation, Harold & Maude, The Long Goodbye, Taxi Driver, not fucking Star Wars. Star Wars and Jaws destroyed everything New Hollywood built and replaced it with '80s blockbusters.

People who say shit like "this is gonna be like a French new wave movie" clearly never sat through a fucking Godard or Truffaut movie. They're incredibly slow, beautiful but empty. Uniformly depressing. I do not believe for two seconds any Disney movie is going to be like them.

@OhPoorPup IIRC that error comes up both when you have problems with the motor or alignment OR if you have a blank disk... or a damaged disk. But I bet the FDS wouldn't know the difference between blank and demagnetized.
@OhPoorPup I guess it's possible it could be partly demagnetized but I've never personally run across and issue where only one side of a disk was demagnetized and the other side was fine.

@OhPoorPup Maybe it really is just side B that's messed up. But I would be looking really close for damage to the physical disk inside the plastic shell... oh and checking the heads to see if crap is coming off on them when you try to read the disk. I've seen that happen before too. :/

@OhPoorPup Hmm one specific disk only? That still makes me suspicious the disk itself is damaged. IIRC most smaller FDS games (ones that don't flip to side B) pretty much just load the entire game into memory and don't load again so I mean if it loads Mario fine with no errors and runs...

The only game I've played close to gameplay like this is Sakura Wars and half of that game is robot fighting.

Once time we looked at the stars together and she told me how excited she was to one day OWN ALL OF THE STARS. She literally wants to run a mad science/military dictatorship AND I HURT HER FEELINGS. Incredible!

Now my grades have crashed (I went from like #19 in my class to #231), no one will talk to me. Even budding dictator Yuina is pissed at me and spreading rumors that I hurt her feelings. When I first asked her out she was like, "Is that an order?" and now her feelings are hurt!

SO I SELECTED YUINA. Nozomi asks what I wished for and I was like, "UHM IT'S SECRET" And she's like, "I wished for ROMANCE! And you know WHO I wanna get closer toooooo?" I felt like such a dick. Lol. This game is incredible.

And the game is like WHO DO YOU WANNA GET CLOSER TO? Even though I went to this new year's thing with Nozomi and she was standing right there I knew I wanted to get closer to Yuina, who is completely megalomaniacal. She wants to conquer outer space. She's incredibly weird.

At one point I was doing really well with Nozomi, the girl who is a swimmer and really into sports and not much else. But they did this new year's thing where you are supposed to wish for something (grades, romance, uh something else I forget) and I was like okay romance.

And it's not when you are doing well with one girl the game rewards you with sexy pin-ups or like Metroid style revealing clothing whatever. It's just they like you and want to do things with you outside of dates you specifically ask for.

I spent so much time trying to fix all the problems I created and apologize that my character's stress stat went through the roof and even though all my academic stats were high, my character got depressed and totally bombed all his midterms. This is really fascinating gameplay.

So I would say the wrong thing and annoy them or accidentally stand them up because I went to the wrong place. I genuinely didn't mean to do either of those things but I did and it happened because I didn't really care, which had huge consequences with everyone else!

And I was trying to avoid the gossip mechanic by doing these date sequences with girls I didn't care about and I kept fucking up. Because I didn't care I was having trouble remembering which girl liked what and where I asked them to meet.

Which is super weird but whatever. The thing that this does, though, is make it so if you are getting numbers of of all these girls you damn well better pay attention to them or everyone will shit talk you and hate you.

And then the game offers you all kinds of ways to fuck up I've never seen in a visual novel with dating elements. There's this system where you have to pay attention to the girls you know and take them out even if you aren't really into them or they will ruin your reputation.

Heartthrob Memorial/Tokimeki Memorial it's way more abstract than that. You have to work on yourSELF before anyone will like you and it's like, having interests in common is very helpful. You need to make yourself attractive in a variety of ways.

All joking aside, the mechanics of this game are very interesting. A lot of visual novels with dating elements are like focused around very transactional relationships. it's like, you pick the right options from the multiple choice test and "earn" affection. Women are prizes.

Spent a pretty good chunk of time playing this game and I have to say Shiori is a sadistic monster. A rumor-monger will who destroy anyone who dares to make her feel un-special. I don't understand how she is the girl everyone wants to get with when she is so obviously a Mean Girl https://t.co/cUVIWAMkYW
Yeessssss. Doctor Hauzer is great. If like you the old Alone in the Dark games but wished they were weirder and more Japanese, don't stop, run to the download button! https://t.co/Q5l1v68oV7

P.S. I want so bad to talk about a thing the plot does to really integrate Batman's leering into the story and make it part of the whole thematically but I just can't. I refuse to spoil it for you. It's so clever. Go watch it yourself.

Definitely works for me. I didn't expect shit going into it and it wasn't even my idea to see it but I ended up completely loving it. With Birds of Prey and The Batman it seems like maybe DC is finally hiring people who know how to make good superhero movies at last. Yay!

And the Joker cameo was bleccccccchhhh and totally unnecessary. Felt studio mandated. I would have trimmed part of the fight scenes at the very end and I would trimmed the rescues and cut the last Bat/Cat scene altogether along with the Joker cameo. But it's still a good movie.

The main flaw with the movie IMO is yes it's overlong and yes the ending is kind of flabby. They really should have cut out about 15 minutes of it and yeah I do like Batman saving people at the end that's great, but it should have ended there instead of still going on.

Incredibly good usage of a Nirvana song, plus Fauré's Requiem, Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 5, some Dean Martin, and an incredible new techno track from Kevin Saunderson, who is a PERSONAL HERO. He collabs with Patrick Topping on that track. Really good music throughout.

The MUSIC is funny. It's like Ave Maria is such a cliche for crime movies/tv shows and The Batman runs it into the fucking ground and has a pretty funny reason for even using the song at all. And a lot of the rest of the soundtrack is just like dark variations on Ave Maria. AND
Anyway to sum it up: Great cast. Everyone's good. Not complaints. I literally did not recognize Colin Ferrell. I had zero clue that was him. There's a lot of funny bits I said nothing about!
So yeah, The Batman doesn't exactly solve that problem but it also doesn't glorify in violence against women the way a lot of noir does.

Neo-noir doesn't exactly fix that. Movies like Chinatown and Body Heat are pretttty misogynistic and I wouldn't say recent ones are necessarily any better about it. From L.A. Confidential to Black Dahlia to hell, even Gone Girl is kinda neo-noir. And they all hate women.

But I mean, noir gonna noir and it's hard to NOT have noir be a least KINDA misogynistic. The original cycle of noir films in the 30s, 40s, and 50s was kind of born out of the anxiety US men returning from WWII felt when they discovered women did just fine without them.

get shot. I super doubt the movie passes the Bechdel test for example.

And it doesn't feel phony or disingenuous at all! It sort of reminds me in a way of Assassination Nation, a movie I REALLY dug, that kind of manages to walk the line between sleazy pulp and genuinely dealing with feminist ideas butttttt

He's not Hannibal Lector he's like Young Bill Gates The Incel Murderer. And he's inspiring people to crime like those Michigan militia idiots who tried to kidnap the governor. This movie is super Millennial (tm). At one point Catwoman complains about rich white male privilege!

I dunno there's so much that's great about this movie. I was worried about "The Riddler is now a serial killer, this must be grimdark!" bit but it's NOT. Yeah he IS a serial killer but he's an internet incel creepo inspiring fucked up weirdos to try kill government officials.

Bruce goes to an injured Alfred in the hospital and immediately confronts him about how he lied to cover up his dad's misdeeds feels extremely real and human. That part's not funny, but it feels real. Yeah he's worried but his also pissed and can't separate those feelings out.

I dunno, Bruce feels like a real person, a real person that's fucked up and weird. And Andy Serkis' Alfred is like, "Hey weirdo, maybe you should care if your entire fortune is stolen! Maybe you could like, donate to the homeless or something!" I love it.
The "is he joking? is he an idiot? or is he secretly brilliant? no wait, he's definitely an idiot! or IS HE?" vibe of this interview is exactly Pattison's Batman and I could not love it more.

It's a natural progression from his work with Cronenberg and movies like the Lighthouse and also, his incredible interviews where he fucks with the interviewer so much they're not sure if he's joking or not. Like this hilarious GQ interview: https://t.co/n71lbmMy6z

At one point he says something dumb and she's like, "You MUST have grown up rich." And it's spot on. He's incredibly perceptive but also so fucking oblivious at the same time. It's fantastic. Pattinson is really fucking great in this role.

In a lot of Batman stories it's like he stoically rejects Catwoman because duty or moral code but in this she kisses him and he's like, "Uh... what's is kiss?" He's like a space alien who has no idea what humans are.
I don't want to ruin all the funny moments, but there are funny bomb moments, there's funny Riddler moments, funny funeral moments, funny Catwoman moments.

SEVERED HUMAN THUMB pressed against a thumb reader on a thumb driver. So good. That is grade A dark humor.

And it never stops being fun having him totally stumped by a riddle and Batman immediately solves it in two seconds and it's always something stupid. But the macabre humor is there too. Like there's a riddle about a thumb drive, right?

I also REALLY like the rapport between Batman and Gordon. Jeffrey Wright from Westworld and The French Dispatch totally kills it as Gordon. Their dynamic is amazing. Yeah, he's the only good cop in a department full of corruption but his dry sense of humor rocks.

And the Batmobile is right fucking behind him AGAIN. It's great. The entire freeway behind him is like 200 cars on fire and he's like, "I did it! I beat him!" And then the Batmobile comes flying out of the fire and crashes down on the road right behind him. Fucking funny as hell.

He drives the car like a fucking MANIAC, chasing a the Penguin through traffic, causing the biggest fucking freeway accident this side of a game of Grand Theft Auto and Penguin keeps going, "Yeah, my incredible driving skills have saved me! He'll never catch me!"

Anyway, he rides a motorcycle a lot but when he finally gets the Batmobile out, oh that moment rules. You know the movie Christine? That Batmobile is like Christine mixed with a '70s muscle car. I could not love it more.

He's covered in smeary eye shadow like a goth after a The Cure show and Alfred's like oh great, here we go again. What femme fatale hurt your feelings this week, Bruce? The look on his face is beautiful.

A lot of the movie has Bruce riding around on a motorcycle wearing way too much eye shadow (so he can swap into Batman mode easily). There's a great moment where he's brooding in the Bat Cave which is more like The Bat Garage (also super funny).
The incongruity between the Cool Hero wiping out and what would be slapstick if it weren't played so straight is just wonderful. I was dying laughing. The tone is just exquisite.

It's so goddamn funny. He just crashes into the ground and bounces several times and makes these goofy grunts as he picks himself up off the pavement and staggers away. Like it COULD be cartoonish slapstick but the movie plays it so straight.

He goes to the top of the building and leaps off as the cops chase him and instead big majestic hang glider bat wings his cape puffs up into flying squirrel membranes and he jumps off and glides down but oh crap there's an overpass and also a bus and BATMAN FUCKING EATS SHIT.

Gordon says there's only one way out of here, the back door, but you've gotta go fast. How's gonna get out? Gordon tells him to punch him! And he fucking CLOCKS Gordon. Just one hit K.O.s him. It's SO funny. I didn't see it coming at all. The entire theatre burst out laughing.

There's this scene where he's captured by the police and Gordon is trying to convince them to not arrest him because he keeps helping them solve crimes and Gordon gets them to clear the room so he can talk to Bats and he's like, "Okay act like we're fighting while we plot".

They're tough guys and he keeps tricking them and pummeling them and it never stops being funny. I believe it follows the comedy rule of threes so it happens three times? I think twice as Batman and a third time as Bruce Wayne. These idiots suck at their job and it's great.

This movie also has running gags! He keeps going to a (I shit you not) a Detroit techno themed club where all the mob bosses and corrupt politicians hang out (and where Catwoman works). And there's these twins that guard the doors.
You know how in '89 it's like, "WHO ARE YOU MAN?" "I'm... Batman!" This one it's like, "Who are you?" And he's like, "I am... uh, vengeance?" That line delivery kills me. It's so good.
He just stomps into scenes and stomps right out of them. Crash! He barely says anything, no Scary Batman Voice, just like a kind of high pitched, sort of inquisitive thing. It's funny.

People are so used to Batman being this combination mythic creature and fucking ninja, to see him more as this dude in big heavy boots who stomps up to a gangsters and they're like, "Who's this doofus?" And break their hands punching his armor is kind of amazing.

And he is ALWAYS STARING. It makes people uncomfortable. It makes ME uncomfortable. But he's also kind of a bumbling doofus. And the tension between him intently leering all the time and crashing around like a bull in a China shop is kind of hilarious.

But what's that I said about it being a black comedy? Oh it definitely is, but you have to understand that the main character in this movie is Creepy but not like actual stalker creepy. See, he's a fucking shut-in weirdo who has no idea how to communicate like a human being.
And he's being gross in first person and it's kind of wobbly handheld stuff and it feels transgressive. It doesn't feel sexy and fun. It feels yucky, like you need to take a shower afterwards.

And later, a lot of Batman's stuff is also first person. Batman does a lot of leering. He leers at crime scenes, soaking up evidence with his eyes. He leers and Catwoman, in her house, comforting her girlfriend, changing her clothes. You feel gross, because he's being gross.

But because so much of the Riddler shit at the start is first person, you feel guilty. It's like the movie is accusing you of being a creep, of spying on this man's family, like you are tacitly approving of the murder this serial killer is committing.

The movie stars with The Riddler watching a politician through binoculars interacting with his family, breathing heavily, being a fucking creep and eventually he

The classic noir cinematography makes you, the audience, into a voyeur. You're eyeballing a woman a part part at a time. Staring at murders. Leering. But it's at a distance, safe. You can feel pleasure at it without feeling guilty. The Batman wants you to feel kind of gross.

But the way it's shot is way more '70s neo-noir than old school noir or Expressionist like 1989 Batman was. I THINK Nolan really wanted to make like Taxi Driver and just completely missed the mark by A LOT, but The Batman here isn't doing that.

She's mixed up with crime bosses and wants him to kill for her or take the fall or something... He has a kind of okay relationship with one cop and the rest of the department wants him dead or in prison. This is all 100% the standard noir playbook. I love noir so it works for me.
The Batman is definitely noir inspired. It's always raining, tons of shadows everyone, femme fatale urging the hero to abandon his moral code in favor of sexy fun times with her.

People are always reacting to the bullshit he's spewing but he NEVER stops no matter how many times he gets his ass kicked. It never stops being funny. All the shit with his cat, his garbage friend, it's all dark but so funny at the same time. And The Batman reminds me of this.

I would argue that Chinatown and The American Friend in particular are kind of self-serious and grim, but The Long Goodbye is a black comedy and it's SO funny but in a quiet way. Instead of the noir voiceover narration, Elliot Gould is constantly talking shit everywhere he goes.

You see a lot of Italian neo-realist and French new wave inspired techniques used in the '70s flicks. Chinatown, The American Friend, and yes, The Long Goodbye all do it. Lots of location shooting, handheld camerawork, first person stuff, long takes that kind of style. https://t.co/fl4VwnfSMP

So you know the Laura Mulvey criticism of The Gaze, where the camera leers at a woman but breaks her body up into pieces? Legs here, knees there, arm here, neck there, through editing? That's used A LOT in noir and Hitchcock was the master of it. '70s neo-noir rejected this.

It is doing a lot of interesting things visually. The classic noir style of shooting was born out of Weimar Germany Expressionist horror and crime movies (Fritz Lang, F.W. Murnau kind of stuff) and you really saw it come to fruition with Billy Wilder and Alfred Hitchcock.

ANYWAY. At last, The Batman. I really like this movie. I kind of expected it to be dreary and grim for obvious reasons, but it's kind of not. Yeah it's still "dark", but it's dark in a film noir kind of way, not in an ugly shitty office building crime movie kind of way. https://t.co/I8pQE98cDB

Any other studio would have given up, like the Universal monster universe that was abruptly aborted after the failure of that horrible Mummy movie. But you know, gotta keep them comic book movie dollars flowing.

It was just a huge miscalculation and why DC movies have been so bad until recently. I still think Birds of Prey is fantastic and The Suicide Squad wasn't bad, but there were a looooot of endless, ponderous, terrible DC movies.

I think the Nolan movies were a dramatic overcorrection against Batman & Robin's failure. It was like, "Well that was REALLY superhero-y so we need to the 100% except opposite. All movies must be joyless and dull to be taken seriously!"

Much like the Nolan movies didn't have anything interesting for Morgan Freeman or Michael Caine to do, BvS has Diane Lane, Laurence Fishburne, and Jeremy Irons and they do nothing and make no impression whatsoever. Possibly the worst superhero movie I've ever seen.

There are zero good performances in BvS. Affleck's terrible. Cavill's terrible. Normally I really like him, too. He's great in The Witcher. Just awful here. I love Amy Adams. She's got nothing to do here. I have no idea what they were thinking with Jesse Eisenberg.

Speaking of grim, joyless, and ugly, Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice is absolutely dreadful. Boring and endless. I mean, the Nolan movies are all overlong as well, but BvS is just interminably. It feels like sitting through dental surgery. Ugly, ugly movie, too.

I think part of the problem with the Nolan films is they are self-conscious about comic books and superheroes and trying desperately to NOT make people think they are superhero movies. They are grim and joyless and ugly and none of the plots make any sense.

And then there's Rises. Anne Hathaway as kinda Catwoman and Joey Gordon-Levitt as kinda Robin have almost nothing to do. And Tom Hardy is just terrible as shouty goofy voiced Bane, almost as terrible as he was as the evil Picard clone in Star Trek: Nemesis. Dreadful movie.

I do like Aaron Eckhart but he should have been playing Bruce Wayne, not Harvey Dent. He's the only character that has any heart to him in the movie and the Two-Face thing at the end feels... flat. Phony.
The plot of "Batman Guantanamo Bay tortures people to stop crime and also the evil plot is to microwave the bay" is both tasteless and incredibly stupid. Sorry.

I am not into the sequels either. Heath Ledger's Joker is joyless, unfunny, un-scary, and people really wanted to think he was great because the actor just died before the movie came out. Everyone wanted so bad for this to be good and it's not.

And all three movies are like these. And everyone is miscast. Katie Holmes and Maggie Gyllenhaal look equally lost and have nothing to do. And then generic martial arts master Ken Watanabe turns out to NOT be the ninja master, it's secretly white guy Liam Neeson, looking bored!

All three Nolan Batman movies look like really elaborate DMV training videos intercut with action scenes from a video game to me. I dunno, it's like either really dull crime film or Gears of War cutscene or something like that, you know?

I don't like how the movie looks visually, either. It's not neon and flashy like Schumacher's movies, and it's not gothic and Expressionistic like Burton's. It's like drab office building crime film. Like what if The Godfather had no sense of style whatever.

Another part of it is Christopher Nolan films never seem to land with me. Sometimes it's stuff that makes no sense (Bruce spends years becoming a ninja and then the first thing he does as Batman is scream and bark at bad guys. The exact opposite of stealth.)

I admit part of it is I don't like Christian Bale much. He was fine as the racist shithead bad guy in Shaft (2000), but I dunno, I get that American Psycho is satire and everything but it's pretty corny and over the top, IMO. He doesn't really DO subtlety.

Then we have a long gap due to B&R's performance and we get Batman Begins. I was working at a movie theatre when Begins was out and saw a lot of audience reactions to it. I didn't share their enthusiasm.

Batman & Robin feels like a movie that really just wants to be gay and is being held back. Like it really should just be gay. It would be so much better. As it is, it's just tedious and not very funny. Some of the action scenes are neat, though, like the air surfing. Still, bad.

Part of it is how bad Schwarzenegger is in every scene. Howling and not funny and a real drag to watch. Part of it is Alicia Silverstone with nothing whatsoever to do. There's a weird thing where Batgirl's Alfred's niece instead of Commissioner Gordon's daughter. Dunno why?

If you manage to make Clooney not charming you done fucked up. Part of it is that Chris O'Donnell goes from rebellious 20-something biker to teenager pushing 30 living with George Clooney and doing karate laundry.

Batman & Robin learned the wrong lessons from Forever. It has dialogue even worse than Returns. Not just terrible ice puns; every line is painful. George Clooney is the dullest Batman yet. No edge whatsoever but also not funny and charming like Adam West.

And Nicole Kidman is pretty compelling as Batman's shrink/love interest, but the movie's plot is dopey, what the hell is Tommy Lee Jones even doing here, and if you stop to think about it for like five seconds nothing makes any sense. Incredible soundtrack, though.

Batman Forever is very campy and flash and fun to watch but also very, very stupid. NGL the Burton movies are also campy, but not "neon cars driving up the side of the building" and Jim Carrey plays the Riddler as an incredible... I dunno, it's almost drag, and I love it.

Same brief background on me and Batman: I really like the first Tim Burton movie because it is a German Expressionist inspired carnival horror show, even if the ending is a little anti-climactic. I like Returns okay but the dialogue is incredibly bad and the plot wanders off.

I was not expecting much from this movie. I didn't watch trailers or pay attention to casting beyond I knew Robert Pattinson was playing Batman. The cast IS really good and Pattison plays Bruce as a fucking rich shut-in weirdo like Howard Hughes with a rubber anti-crime suit.

I saw The Batman last Friday and despite a kind of rambly over-long denouement, I really liked but I'm definitely expecting lots of people will not appreciate that it is a black comedy noir. @getterdrill Oh right and the nice looking Britai is Robotech MEPTOYS from last year.

@getterdrill Two huge Regult battlepods and Glaug officer's pod are Robotech/Exosquad '90s, shorter Roy VF-1S on the right is Yamato 1/60 v1 circa... 2002 maybe? And the slightly taller HIkaru VF-1S Strike is the Yamato 1/60 v2 from 200... I wanna say 8? Something like that!

@getterdrill Pic four: Boldolzaa, generic Zentradi guy, Ugly Britai, and Ugly Miria are '80s Matchbox Robotech, red Queadluun-Rau is Yamato 1/60... 200... 4? Pretty Miria is CM's (she has an optional wedding dress body and long hair head) 200... 4? Hikaru VF-1J and Zentradi guy are Arii '80s.

@getterdrill The three Regults battlepads (regular and two different missile types) are all from the Toynami Robotech vinyls from like 2010ish? And in front, the VF-2SS SAP ('18) and VF-4 Hikaru (20...20? What year is it?) are both Bandai Hi-Metal R 1/100ish.

@getterdrill Picture 3: All four Destroids, the Spartas hovertank from Southern Cross, the Bioroid from SC, and the Nousjadeul-Ger power armor are from the '94-'95 Robotech/Exo-Squad crossover line that reissued the '80s Matchbox stuff again, Dana/Jeanne from SC is the '80s Matchbox...

@getterdrill And behind 2003 VF-1S Super Roy is 1983 Takatoku VF-1S Super Roy (well I guess actually the Skull One Supers are all technically Hikaru since Roy was dead by then whatever). In the back is the Bandai/Matchbox SDF-1 from the Robotech '80s line... <Gasps for breath>

@getterdrill 1/55 Valkyries in front left VF-1S Max is a Bandai 2008 Origin of Valkyrie reissue, the VE-1 Elintseeker is '84 Bandai, the Roy VF-1S Super on the right is 2003 Bandai reissue. Behind Max is 1990 reissue Bandai VF-1S Super Roy, behind VE-1 is Hikaru VF-1S Strike Bandai '84...

@getterdrill The incredibly tiny chibi Valkyries are '80s Select Convertors, which are US releases of the Takatoku Paro (as in parody) Valkyries. They're like the size of a silver dollar. The teeny VF-17S is a '90s Macross 7 gashapon type thing.

@getterdrill Picture 2: The chibi VF-1S Roy and VF-1J Max are the Robotech '80s releases of the Takatoku Joke Machine Valks but the VF-1A Hikaru is the Bandai DYRL version so '84. Tiny model kit on the right is Testors R.O.B.O.T. '80s, but they're US versions a Japanese model I can't remember
@getterdrill VF-2SS is the Evolution Toys 1/60 from about 5 years ago! Fits super great with the 1/60 Macross 7 and 1/55 VF-1 toys, though!

@getterdrill Big VF-1A Hikaru is the 2002 1/55 Bandai reissue, the gray VF-1J 1/55 is the Matsushiro UK release that came out between Takatoku Toys going under and Bandai taking up the license for DYRL, so 83ish, Armored VF-1S in the back is the '80s Takatoku giftset...

@getterdrill <Deep Breath> Roy, Hikaru/Rick, Misa/Lisa '80s Matchbox, models on the left and right side are Arii kits from the '80s IIRC, the little VF-1A in the center is the Bandai 1984 DYRL 1/100, VF-17D and S, Fire Valkyrie, and VF-19S are all '90s Bandai 1/60...

@getterdrill That Minmay is technically from the early '90s I believe... she was designed for the '80s Matchbox line but not released at the time due to sexism, but Harmony Gold rereleased most of the Matchbox Robotech line in I think 1991? Something like that. As for everything else...

I'm pretty pleased with Hathaway overall but I would not be shocked if people were advising others to just wait until the second movie is out and watch them together. It doesn't end on a cliffhanger or anything but it's a serious case of I WAS JUST GETTING INTO IT. WHAT'S NEXT? https://t.co/ZGnSqGVchC

GONNA BE A WAIT.

Not exactly what I was expecting, does not do the shit I was worried it was going to, and mostly I dig it. Also really nice animation and not too much  "oh here is a cg bot that sticks out super badly from the background thing" that annoys me in modern anime.

I heard some people say Hathaway was kind of anti-climatic because Hathaway didn't murder Lane or step on Kenny or anything but I thought it was a pretty satisfying ending to part one. But the second I finished I was like, "So when does part two come out??"

Didn't see that shit coming either. Very interesting. Plus I absolutely dig the cat and mouse game between Hathaway and his true rival, Federation captain Kenneth Sleg. That is the real meat. It's kind of like young hot Ranba Ral versus Amuro 2.0 and I'm down for that, you know? https://t.co/LYALFbVkSS

Xi Gundam, you're so sharp! Anyway their duel is pretty interesting not so much because of pilots of a similar skill level fighting desperately but rather because of the part where Aim has one of Hathaway's crew as a hostage but GIVES HIM TO HATHAWAY because he's a man of honor. https://t.co/GOjPi7AA62
@Kaikairos No worries, it's twitter. Everything's shitposty!
Lane Aim is a hilariously Tomino-ass name, too. Penelope isn't as cool as the Xi Gundam, but it's still pretty cool. Bless your pointy little heart, Penny. https://t.co/sWgMIHB4qO

I also like that the Bad Guy Robot, the Penelope, is piloted by a really skilled test pilot who were are explicitly told has little real world experience and fucking sucks in combat.  It's like if Chris from 0080 had to fight Char or something.
I also like the thing where they have to space to pick up the Xi Gundam out of its secret box and it's a really heartstopping moment when they almost knock that shit away into spaceeeee. Well done.

Shocking destruction and violence AND it really makes giant robots seem terrifying again from their sheer scale along. A big fucking robot could easily kill a ton of people without even trying and Hathaway rams that fact home.
Like the terrorists are absolutely morally correct and it seems like most of the local civilians are actually 100% on board with Mafty and WANT them to attack but when it actually happens, holy shit.

It's easy to make destruction when fighting a broadly corrupt and indifferent fascist government seem cool and fun instead of terrifying and bleak, even if necessary. I kind of feel like James Bond-y spy hijinks and titillation aside, Hathway is the Battle of Algiers of Gundam.
This is the best "oh my god, civilians are dying everyone war is hell" in Gundam since probably F91. Everything's in flames.

She can't stop crying, she tries to grab her burning purse and he yanks her away from fire. Hathaway seeing the actual carnage he unleashed up close and personal, happening to a woman he clearly has the hots for is a really interesting inversion of the whole James Bond formula.

It feels like half the movie but it's prolly 15 minutes. Instead of getting picked up by his Mafty crew, Hathaway stays with Gigi and helps her survive the attack he engineered and it's TERRIFYING. Giant robots collapsing buildings almost on top of them, everything on fire.

BUT that said, they went from "Hathaway stops an airplane hijacking with the help of his rough and tumble rival whose name recalls Sleggar Law" and "can he super spy his way out of being IDed by the authorities as notorious villain with a dumb name MAFTY?" to WAR TRAUMA

@Kaikairos Also: If you were looking at Breakout/Arkanoid/whatever from the top, the paddle would be like narrow, not wide, wouldn't it? Plus the additional shading and shit in Arkanoid's paddle reinforces that. So contrasting that with Pong...

@Kaikairos Well I guess I would have to look very closely at Breakout specifically versus Arkanoid, Alleyway, Blockbuster etc and compare values or whatever, but there's still the fact that there's stuff on top you hit and the paddle is on the bottom and that for sure reads side view.
Like Gigi is definitely SOMEONE on staff's fetish. Compare her character design thing to Hathaway's. https://t.co/Tf6XzozfF0

I watched the movie and I was pretty surprised with the whole soft sensitive boy James Bond thing Hathaway has going on and I kid of dig it. They maybe went a little hard with the "CAN a sexy 20 year old probably Newtype woman make Hathaway reconsider blowing up civilians?" thing

Anyway, I DO like the idea of Hathaway as an anti-fascist Federation terrorist and I was really interested in seeing if they could:

A) Make him likeable again
B) Do something interesting with the whole terrorist angle

Like would they do something AEUG-like with him? Or not?

There needs to be a counseling service for late-career b-movie directors to either teach them how to make the right kind of b-movies in the streaming era or teach them how to return to civilian life. There's still time. You can rejoin the world!

He also directed 13 movies with titles like "1313: X". I am serious. 1313: Nightmare Mansion. 1313: Actor Slash Model. It just goes on and on. He also directed A Talking Pony?! in addition to A Talking Cat?! He'll make any old garbage now. Just confusing and weird.

Maybe he and Wynorski should have done what Rick Sloane did and just stop making b-movies after the '90s ended. I mean, Sloane will always be the guy who made Hobgoblins and the Vice Academy movies. But DeCoteau directed 17 TV movies whose titles like "The Wrong X".

Like how do you go from Bowl-O-Rama to Santa's Summer House? Like he was never some fancy auteur or whatever, but one is an objectively fun b-movie and the other is bewildering and impossible to set through.

I don't know if it was a digital taking off or a change in Hollywood or whatever, but like Wynorski, he went from making entertaining trash to just stiff, unwatchable dreck that I can't even imagine why someone paid to have it made.

He also did sequels to stuff you've probably seen. Puppet Master III, Retro Puppet Master, Puppet Master: Blitzkrieg Massacre, Prehysteria! 3. But much like Jim Wynorski, something terrible happened in the 2000s.

He directed a million trash movies but my favs are the '80s ones with Linnea Quigley livening them up, like Sorority Babes in the Slimeball Bowl-O-Rama, Nightmare Sisters, and she even shows up in Dr. Alien.

And it co-stars Jessica Morris, a soap opera star, who was in those movie AFTER she had been in every episode of One Life To Live for years and years. How? Why? Also this is directed by David DeCoteau under a female pseudonym, just like A Talking Cat?! Maybe you know DeCoteau.

I watched Santa's Summer House because of @Rifftrax and everything about this movie is confusing. Robert Mitchum's son plays a beardless Santa Claus in a Cynthia Rothrock movie in which she does zero fighting. It's filmed in the A Talking Cat?! McMansion in SoCal. https://t.co/dgi5ctGr55

I did figure out, though, that if I load one of these Pokemon games and then reset the SNES it actually brings up the Super Game Body borders and color palettes, which I did not expect. Well that is just interesting there.

The other three, Yellow, Blue, and Red all seem to be the normal American releases of those three games except again, garbled monster graphics. The usual professional Nintendo localizations it looks like.

Like Pokemon is written P K M N in a little box. Like they couldn't expand the ROM I'm guessing. The writing is really stilted and clipped and weird and also the Prof. Oak graphics are garbled on these two as well as the monsters themselves. Weird.

RT @MikeJMika: @whydoisay I cannot articulate how excited I was to see the game on pirate carts in the 90s. I felt like I finally made it.
@hellodonavon That's Wizards & Warriors X: The Fortress of Fear, Rare's extremely mediocre platformer based on their wobbly NES series most known for really great music and Fabio box art.

Boxxle 1 and Boxxle 2 so you've got all your Sokoban needs met. The weird Snoopy's Magic show is here and it's another bad puzzle game. A number of old Atari arcade ports, too. Missle Command, Centipede, Serpent is a varitant of Blockade/Snake/Tron Light Cycles/whatever!
Plus there's all the annoying puzzle games you can handle. Kwirk, Flipull, Hatris (Pajitnov of Tetris fame presents Yoshi... with hats! Instead of Mario characters!)

The GB Minesweeper (Soukaitei) was I believe a Japanese exclusive! Weird. Oh, there's also Dropzone, an old Commodore 64 game that is kind of like Defender meets Jetpac. There's also Castelian (which is under its US name rather than Kyoro-Chan Land) was Nebulus on '80s computers.

There are definitely several ports of weird Western PC games that were legit GB releases like Crystal Quest, Shanghai, and no kidding, Minesweeper, like the crappy free game that came with Windows during the entire 1990s. This is NOT from MS The Best of Entertainment Pack for GBC

Spot is not Spot's Cool Adventure but instead a pretty dull Othello-ish puzzle game starring the 7-Up mascot, rather than a cartoony platformer. Oh also, it's amusing that this cart has both Penguin Land AND Penguin Wars, for all your penguin needs.

VS Battler is the game we got in the US as Bionic Battler, Pit Man is the Japanese name for Cattrap, and so on. Other oddities. Space Invaders is a standalone port without the cool SNES Super Game Boy enhanced version.
For example, Kingof The Zoo is what we got as Penguin Wars, or Penguin-kun Wars Vs. in Japan. Yeah, it's King of the Zoo in Europe for some reason.

Tank War is just a repeat of Battle City and Master Fighter is just a repeat of Master Karateka. Strangely, some of these are the Japanese versions (fair # of Japanese exclusive games in fact), some are American versions, and weirdly, some are European.

Loopz and Pipe Dream are not LITERALLY the same game, but they're BASICALLY the same game. I think Loopz was a contemporary ripoff of Pipe Dreams? I'm not even sure Pipe Dreams was the originator of the concept anyway. But they are both legit releases pirated on this cart.

But this isn't a hack; it was really released that way in Japan. The original Famicom version we got as Bugs Bunny's Crazy Castle on NES was called Roger Rabbit in Japan! So many reskins of the same game!

I thought Mickey Mouse would be Mickey Mousecapade bc on Famicom it was just called Mickey Mouse IIRC, but it's actually Crazy Castle, which is to say, the same game that is also on here as Bugs Bunny or more properly, Bugs Bunny's Crazy Castle.

There's also a bunch of repeats, as usual. Dragon Slayer and Dragon Story, Star Fighter and Star War are both Starfight. Bomber Man is NOT Bomberman but rather a repeat of Irem's Bombjack. Moto Racing, like Motocross is Motocross Maniacs.

@toysdream Now you are making me wonder if there are direct sources, interviews from the '80s or something with Tomino or Yaz or somebody talking about how bad they thought the Axis drop would be.
@toysdream And I still can't get over the idea that Char would use the same tactics as the horrible Zabi family, except even worse. I just can't accept that Char would become Gihren 2.0.

@toysdream Really? Maybe the Tomino and company weren't up on the science or whatever but the colony drop on Australia sure seemed to make the entire continent dead. I don't recall seeing trees or animals or anything. And that's way smaller than Axis.
@toysdream I'd love to hear that those volumes say, but yeah at the minimum we're talking mass extinction event.
@toysdream Like I could MAYBE buy it if he was releasing an engineered virus that would kill all the humans on earth or something like that.
@toysdream I'm pretty sure he and Sayla had a conversation about how foolhardy it was.

@toysdream Does mass extinction of all earth species aside from humanity really square with Char pre-CCA? I don't think it does. And I don't think he was a big fan of the colony drop either. Wasn't he saying stuff about how eerie and haunted Texas Colony was after that genocidal attack?

@toysdream I mean I guess I would have to rewatch Zeta to find exact Char quotes but we're not talking about killing all humans on earth, even if life would eventually return it would still kill off almost every living species on earth. Like maybe bacteria or viruses would survive.

Furthermore, why would Char want to commit the kind of genocidal war crime that the Zabi family did. He literally killed most of them not only because they betrayed his family and killed his father, but because they were genocidal! I just don't remotely buy the entire premise.

I'm sure they wanted a giant threat for their big movie and they wanted it to be the final showdown between Amuro and Char to sort of wrap that story up, but "kill earth with an asteroid" doesn't track. At all.

Char's stated goal was to get humans to leave earth and become spacenoids and hopefully Newtypes and allow earth to recover. Even if you don't think corrupt political bodies can be reformed, destroying every species alongside humanity doesn't make sense.

The plan in Megazone 23 where they forced every human to leave other and built a giant space death gun to kill any humans who came back to earth with the wrong attitude makes sense. The idea was to allow nature to recover and force humanity to expand out in the stars. But CCA?

Great work, Mark! Loved read this. It still doesn't make me buy Char's change of character between Zeta and CCA, though. It still makes no sense. He wants to save the earth... by destroying it. ? Talking about humanity's arrogance towards nature and... continuing that arrogance? https://t.co/W6lsr5ZEL0

So I mean, you don't get to hear "The Future Is Now", but still it's rad to see. I hope some fan with more time than sense re-edits the HD footage into a really nice and accurately boring HD version of Robotech The Movie for completeness' sake. THE END! Enjoy the VHS rips.

But the BEST bonus feature on the AnimEigo MZ23 is... wait for it... a HD version of the Robotech The Movie opening credits moons and space and crap but also the happy ending! It has a generic soundtrack with a voiceover explaining the backstory instead of the Robotech audio.

Plus the AnimEigo MZ23 BDs have incredible bonus features including the weird Johnny Winters international dub of Megazone 23 Part Two that I never found a VHS copy of (it also strangely censors the movie a little bit, sex scene is shorter for example).

Anyway, I love Megazone. One of my all-time favs, so you know I backed AnimEigo's Megazone 23 Blu Ray Kickstarter and you know my name is on the credits on those BDs. That shit is amazing and you should buy them immediately if you haven't already. Fantastic work.

Anyway, I would still really like a Hargun in the same scale as my Yamato Garland and a hover Garland an EX-Garland and all that shit would be cool but I don't know if I can trust large scale Megazone 23 toys anymore. :/ Also why are the new ones so incredibly expensive? Ugh.

I did buy the 1/60 VF-4G but I bought it from Arcadia. And I ended up selling it because it was an hours long excruciating process to transform it and I'm way happier with the Bandai Hi-Metal R 1/100 VF-4. It's Hikaru's VF-4, which is what I wanted in the first place.

I did buy the cute little Organic Hobby mini Megazone figures as well (super hyped to have a Hargun and a Space Hargun and the hover Garland from Megazone 23 Part Two at last!) but I was so soured on two bum Yamato Garlands I literally never bought another Yamato toy.

It has Gold Plastic Syndrome. Fucking fell apart when my friend was helping me move. SUCH A DISAPPOINTMENT. You would not believe how upset I was, but trying not to ACT upset around my friends and GF.

I later sold the brown Garland and just kept the figures. And then I got the Proto Garland from Megazone 23 Part Two which I LOVED. Even nicer than the original one. I was very happy with it, until I moved in 2011. Why? There's a lot of bronze-ish gold plastic and on it. Yeah.

I waited months and months for a replacement part and I finally got it and installed it and actually, yep, that fixed it, and it was fine from then one. Still have it. No problems. I bought the brown recolor so I could have the figures it came with mostly (Yui and Shogo's buddy).

But I got my Garland in the mail, had already heard about failures, and GINGERLY AND SLOWLY AS HELL transformed it. Seemed find. I set it on my shelf in robot mode. And then without even touch it like an hour later the arm just fucking fell off. The joint just disintegrated.

At the time I had had one of the 1/60 v1 Valkyries (or maybe my then-GF did?), the cannon fodder brown one, and I THINK I bought the 1/48 huge DYRL Hikaru VF-1S by that point so I had not been burned.

Anyway, the next Megazone story I have is I was super hyped by Yamato releasing toys of the Garland from MZ23 and of course I preordered. I had never been burned by shitty Yamato quality control and/or super poor design but most of my friends had and were mad.

Borgman, if you don't know, is KIND of a follow up to Zillion. Lots of the same people involved, similar kind of show, yadda yadda. If you like Zillion it's worth checking out. Oh yeah, plus I also got another DVD for answering MZ23 trivia, I think it was Generator Gawl? IDK.

No one else could answer a SINGLE MZ23 trivia question. By answering the questions I got the second ADV Megazone 23 DVD for free, before it came out officially, plus the Sonic Soldier Borgman OVAs (I don't think we ever got the whole show, just the sequel OVAS.)

So I got the first ADV Megazone 23 DVD along with the expensive art box that had like a mouse pad in it and then the summer of 2004 I went to Anime Expo in I want to say Anaheim? I went to the ADV panel and they kept asking Megazone 23 questions and I answered every single one.

In like 2003? ADV announced they got the Megazone 23 license! I was SO HYPED. Finally, good quality DVD releases of all of Megazone! Also maybe they would do Robotech The Movie since they had both licenses! (They did not, though the non-Megazone parts were bonus features later.)

Woof. Robotech The Movie is boring, folks. So following that ADV got the Robotech license and started putting out DVDs, AnimEigo got the Macross license and I spent most of the money I earned working at Kaybee Toys that winter into preordering their SDF Macross set and...

I snapped it up, took it home, and watched it with my then-girlfriend and my friend Jim. Annnnnd I literally fell asleep during the movie. I believe it was around the Southern Cross footage where they shoot down one of the Zor/Masters ships using a Death Star trench run.

When I got the post I was like, "Okay I FINALLY need to see Robotech The Movie, dammit!" And then I went to a toy show in San Jose and there it was, at a bootleg VHS tape dealer's table. This would have been 2000 I think.

I've had it ever since. It's in my bedroom rn. Turns out the guy who sold it to me won it in a contest from Academy Comics! I guess Harmony Gold supplied them with leftover Robotech artifacts they had hanging around L.A. He entered and won the contest and then sold it to me.

THEN later I found an AMAZING thing. It was I think the summer of '99 and I found an ebay auction for a theatrical poster of Robotech The Movie. No, it was not some weird bootleg poster and now it was not in Spanish or whatever, an actual American movie poster in English. I won.
This was probably 1997? I dunno. It was after I got my Megazone 23 Streamline tape but before I got the fansubs IIRC. It's just a very very weird artifact.

I found Megazone 23 art books at local bookstores, bought them online, et cetera. Academy Comics did a bewildering comic adaptation of Robotech The Movie that dramtically changed the ending, added some weird Dirty Pair ripoff stuff, modified the Southern Cross bits dramatically.
(They filled out that latter tape with a Slayers special as well. Neat bonus feature!) So that's where I got the VHS fansubs of the Megazone OVAs! And I LOVED them so much. Loved loved loved.

I already got DYRL and several volumes of Macross 7 from Acefly and I found out that Kodacha Anime had Megazone 23! So I got Megazone 23 Part One, Part Two, Megazone 23 III Parts One and Two, and of course, Macross 7 The Movie: The Galaxy's Calling Me!

Unfortunately, Nikaku wanted $30 for it so I didn't buy it right away, hoping to find it cheaper. I never did so I bit the bullet and bought it, overpriced as it was. I LOVED IT. LOVED IT. So damn good. Then I found out from the Internet there were sequels, not released here.

I found it again! At Nikaku Animart, the rad store that had all kinds of VHS tapes, laser discs, and art books about anime. It was (is?) a store above some boring Japanese home furnishings store in San Jose's Japantown and I got soooo much good stuff there.

I originally saw it for sale in a mall, probably Vallco, but I didn't have enough allowance for it and got whatever Robotech novel I needed next instead. By the time I came back for it later it was gone. Then after I started going to CA West at the San Jose branch library...

But it's done well enough. The dub is perfectly serviceable. This is how I first saw Megazone 23. I didn't see Robotech The Movie until afterwards... and I'm glad about that. So I didn't get this until 1996 or 1997?

This VHS release of Megazone 23 Part One is kind of Macek apologizing for the disaster that was Robotech The Movie and doing it right. Yes, it includes Robotech staff (Greg Snegoff wrote the localization based on a raw Japanese translation, familiar Robotech voice actors, etc).

Because it was 1995, the back of the box copy has some nonsense about virtual reality, which is a HUGE stretch, but also Macek knew his audience of teenage and early 20s nerds was the actual Megazone 23 audience so here's a naked chick on the back of the box. That's Eve, BTW. https://t.co/unQGkpG9aE

So I'm finding out about all this in 1995. You know what else happens in 1995? Carl Macek, Robotech's producer started his own company to dub and distribute mostly uncut anime in America and guess what they released that year? Megazone 23 Part One on VHS. That's this tape!

... but also because of Cannon's financial woes. But Cannon did what they always did with their bombs: throw it haphazardly into foreign markets. That's how you get the UK release, but there's also VHS releases in various Central and South American countries!

So you're advertising a movie intended for late teens early 20s audiences to kindergarteners. I don't care how much Southern Cross footage or happy endings you add, it's still not a little kiddie show. It was bad. The national release was canned, not just because of the poor test

Megazone was definitely aimed at the latter audience, prolly even aged more bc it came out in 1985, 3 years after Macross and some of that audience was now in college and/or working their first jobs with some disposable income. You had to be to buy these expensive ass VHS tapes.

Gundam and Macross and shows like that really had two audiences: The kids they were trying to sell toys to, and older people, mostly teens and college students who were into the character drama and building model kits and the like.

You see, the movie was test marketed in Dallas in the mid-'80s where it was shown against shit like Aliens and completely smoked at the box office. Also they drew the wrong audience, like kids who were into GoBots and Megazone is... not that.

This gives Megazone a stupid incongruous happy ending but I do have to say, the '80s synth pop ballad The Future Is Now they end on fucking rules, so there's that. Anyway I heard about all this stuff from the Robotech ML because one or two people on the ML actually saw it.

So not only was Cannon mad that Megazone didn't have enough action, they were mad about the downer ending. So they did commission a few minutes of new footage, apparently via Idol Co. but IIRC actually animated by AIC, not Artland/Artmic.

And they cram in all this out of context SC footage that makes the movie feel TWO HUNDRED YEARS LONG and changes what is a super fun sci-fi action anime with a just smart enough sci-fi twist and a downer Yakuza movie ending like Sympathy for the Underdog into something very slow.

Also due to licensing rights re: Macross they couldn't really use Macross footage so they recycled Southern Cross footage, which was shot on 16mm and Megazone was 35mm bc it was supposed to be theatrical. It clashes. The time period is changed to immediately before Southern Cross

Originally Robotech The Movie inserts Megazone into the Robotech timeline between Macross and Southern Cross and is supposed to lead into Sentinels. Cannon ruins that plan by demanding a bunch of changes and wanting new footage they can't afford.

Except unlike TV they needed a film distributor and the one they got was b-movie schlockmeisters Cannon Films, who were in the process of imploding due to years of bad business and the failure of their Superman sequels and Masters of the Universe didn't help.

The extremely short version is the producers of Robotech wanted a Robotech movie, DYRL was tied up with different licenses because Toho was involved, so they wanted something similar and a bunch of Macross and Mospeada staff worked on Megazone 23 and it was available, so BAM.
If you don't know the story of Robotech The Movie, I talked about it a bit in my Zillion/Sentinels/Robotech The Movie thread here: https://t.co/YoE1Zj4XXL

So I moved to California in 1995 and got regular Internet access, found The Robotech Mailing List, an email discussion group, and that's where I found out Robotech The Movie was NOT Clash of the Bionoids and was in fact, very rare in the US.

Later issues explained the transition between Macross and Robotech: The Macross Saga and now I went what anime (or Japanimation ugh) was, and retroactively realized Voltron and Tranzor Z, not to mention Mysterious Cities of Gold, Noozles, Adventures of the Little Koala were too.

Anyway, I called asking for Robotech: The Macross Saga #1, they said they had it, I came in and they gave me MACROSS #1. For a half second I was thinking, "That's wrong" but the SDF-1 was there on the cover and so was a Valkyrie. Mind expanded.

That store, I think it was called Galaxy Comics?, was on Murphy Street in Sunnyvale and was victim of early '90s gentrification when the city of Sunnyvale decided Murphy was going to be the fancy downtown street with expensive restaurants and high class bars. Boo.

I was calling local Sunnyvale, CA comic stores asking for Robotech: The Macross Saga #1 and one store, R&K, tried to sell me Robotech: The Masters #1, which was wrong. Another shop, a SUPER cool store sold my mom the original G1 Optimus Prime boxed in 1992 for my birthday.
I actually first found out that Macross was a separate anime combined with Southern Cross and Mospeada and edited and dubbed into Robotech via the Comico comics.

Then, as detailed in my Macross VHS rip thread, I found Clash of the Bionoids at a Suncoast in 1993 or 1994? For a while I assumed Robotech The Movie was some dub of this. It wasn't. https://t.co/FOlCEZLa4F

I tried desperately to find out anything about but I couldn't. Years came and went. I got Macross II comics. A friend had the abridged FHE tapes of the Macross parts of Robotech (6 VHS tapes for the whole story more or less with slower parts/episodes cut out) and I loved it.
There were a bunch of Robotech related ads in these comics. Toys, the RPG, stuff like that but also, mysteriously, COMING SOON... ROBOTECH THE MOVIE. THERE WAS A MOVIE???!!

I browsed through it and found an issue of Comico's adaptation of Robotech: The Macross Saga. The episode where the Zentradi have captured our heroes and force them to kiss. Mind blown, I spent the rest of the summer discovering comic book stores and hunting down Macross issues.

And then in I think 1991? I was on a trip with my family in the summer and we visited some ghost town in California that had been turned into a historical tourist trap kind of thing and for some reason they had an antiques store there with a box full of old comics in there.
Anyway, Robotech left the airwaves where I lived in Michigan and all Robotech material kind of disappeared around me but I kept the toy and remembered the show fondly.

I was positive it would transform like Jetfire and was in fact expecting just Jetfire but way larger. It did not. I disassembled it with a screwdriver trying to get it to transform. It didn't. I put it back together and settled for it the way it was.

I never saw the Southern Cross or Mospeada parts of Robotech as a kid and I don't think I even saw the post-war Macross episodes, but it was a watershed moment for me and I got the big ugly non-transformable Veritech Fighter from Matchbox for my birthday in I dunno '86? '87?

How did I find out about Megazone 23? Well, I was a kid in the '80s, got Transformers Jetfire for Christmas one year, and then was stoked to see Robotech later and realize there was an entire show about Jetfires.

I also want to single out Animation Director Ichiro Itano, also of Macross fame. You know his trademark technique, the Itano Circus, with missiles flying everyone. Both he and Aramaki went on to be directors as well.

You can read the staff roll at the end of the video or look at creds on ANN or whatever, but you will see a ton of other big names. Original story is by Ishiguro and Aramaki, screenplay by Hiroyuki Hoshiyama who worked Macross (four eps), Dirty Pair, Lily C.A.T., Vifam, Layzner.

You may've noticed that Megazone 23 is like Mospeada and Bubblegum Crisis bc it features motorcycles that transform into combat robots! This is kind of an Aramaki (and to a lesser extent Kakinuma) trademark! The Garland, the hero cycle from MZ23, is one of the all-time greats.

Additional mecha design work was done by Gaku Miyao and Masayoshi Kubota but AFIAK, that's stuff like those flying gunship thingies and cars and whatever. It's mostly Aramaki and Kakinuma on the robots and fancy shit.

Part One was directed by Ishiguro, Chief Director of the original SDF Macross TV show as well as Co-Director of Macross: Do You Remember Love? The mecha designs were by Shinji Aramaki and Hideki Kakinuma, both of whom worked on Mospeada and BGC and Kakinuma on Gall Force too.

Part One was a collaboration between Artmic, Artland, and Idol Co., though other smaller people were involved as well in various capacities. You know Artmic from Mospeada, Bubblegum Crisis, et cetera and you know Artland from Macross.

Part One was of course originally titled just Megazone 23 on release. It was an early OVA but not the first: Oshii's Dallos beat it to market, as did some porn! It was basically created to be a feature film but in the Miracle Economy, it was a massive success.

It's good time to talk about staff. Eve's character designer is Haruhiko Mikimoto of Macross fame, but the rest are by Toshiki Hirano of the Iczer stuff. And Eve's design in the series is definitely draw by the regular staff and yeah Eve in the original Megazone looks p Hirano.

It went through several name changes (Vanity City, Omegazone, yadda yadda) during this whole process and the character that was originally a resistance pirate DJ turned into a holographic idol singer named Eve.

If you're not familiar with Megazone 23, the gist is it was originally going to be full TV show but a sponsor pulled out and the rare conditions of the '80s bubble economy allowed for them to get enough funding to complete a single direct to video feature.

And it's a Megazone 23 III audio drama, too, not Shogo and friends. A really cool feature I didn't want to get lost to time. That's kind of what inspired me to preserve all this stuff in the first place!

Megazone 23 III (NOT Megazone 23 Part Three by the way... it's one of those years later OVA sequels that takes place years later and is sort of maybe in continuity like Macross II or Orguss 02) includes the coolest bonus feature of all: a fansub of an official audio drama.

Plus there are BONUS FEATURES on the Kodacha fansubs! MZ23 Part One includes a parody fansub of the first episode of Evangelion. Part Two includes a fansub of Prescence, MZ23 Part Two character designer Umetsu's short in the Robot Carnival collection.

Enjoy my Megazone 23 VHS rip quintuple threat! 

We've got a Robotech The Movie PAL to NTSC conversion! We've got Megazone 23 Part One the Streamline dub! We've got vintage Kodacha Anime fansubs of Megazone 23 Part One, Two, and III!

If we get a legit Western release of the movie on BD and it includes only the FB2012 ending I'm not going to complain, but I'd rather have branching pathways to watch which version we'd prefer. Hell, go all out and include the international dub. But until then, you have this.

I guess it's cool that they added Minmay's concert from FB2012 to the end of the movie, but I mean, the art style doesn't look the same and it just sticks out. It feels really weird. I think the FB2012 footage may have been shot on 16mm instead of 35mm. It doesn't work for me.

The 3 versions of DYRL I've uploaded today are different from the commonly available DVD and BD rips you'll find out there. The subtitles aren't the same as the fansub and the ending is different. One of the BD releases blurs gore (not the most recent) and is DNRed to death.

(Because I was again a very cool teen and not a dork, I got the VF-17D for Christmas, but in my defense, I later gave it to my first serious girlfriend and she was so happy about it she cried. A few years ago I bought another one on eBay.)

And I also know that Christmas for some reason several local comic book stores, R&K Comics in Sunnyvale and Legends in Vallco Fashion Park, a mall in Cupertino, got imports of Bandai's four 1/65 Valkyries from Macross 7.

I know I got DYRL and the first three volumes of Macross 7 in 1996 or maybe early '97 because it was not long after the first couple of tapes of Macross Plus came out from Manga but it was before the entire OVA was here and before the movie. It was after I started Escaflowne.

Acefly was rad because they didn't make me mail them a blank tape. I would send them a money order that I bought at the local post office and they would mail me back really high quality VHS tapes with uh, semi-decent quality video on them!

I found this website Acefly Distribution Service, either from one of the Robotech/Macross email lists I was on or maybe it was the Anime Web Turnpike and I ordered DYRL and the first three volumes of Macross 7, followed later by more M7 and Megazone 23, Slayers et cetera.
Our school's anime club imploded because why would we go back to that when we could just spend an entire Saturday watching brand new stuff in San Jose

Two things occurred to me at this point: 

1) I could probably find specific anime fansubs I wanted via the Internet rather than just watching whatever CA West spoonfed me
2) My stepmom is Japanese and when I'd visit she'd show me tapes of random Japanese TV, so why not anime?

I remember watching Cowboy Bebop when it was new, unsubtitled, with this running commentary translation in the dark of a branch library in San Jose. Did I mention we were EXTREMELY COOL TEENS and not FUCKING NERDS?

If we were lucky, the source was a first gen VHS tape recorded off of TV or in some special occasions, a LASER DISC. Ooo, ahh. But usually it was second gen. We also got to see raw Japanese shows with one of the few guys there who spoke Japanese clumsily interpreting on the fly.

Then he was like, "Hey next weekend come with me to San Jose, to the library in Japantown." It was a thing called CA West, Club Anime West. 10 or 12 VCRs daisy chained together copying VHS tapes made by using Amiga with genlock to superimpose amateur subtitles over anime.
So we went to the Art Room at lunch once a week and watched Escaflowne fansubs, Gunsmith Cats, stuff like that.

I was such a cool teen that I was in the short-lived anime club. An older kid (he was probably 17 lol) told me and my friends Elven, George, and Stephanie that we were missing out by watching Robotech reruns on KTEH, the local PBS channel out of San Jose.

In the early days of the World Wide Web (not the Internet bc c'mon, that was around way before the '90s) I got into the dirty, dirty world of VHS fansubs starting in 1996, which I can date because the first fansub I ever saw was Escaflowne, still airing in Japan in fact!
Are the acting and awkward localization worse then the US Renditions dub (later reissued by Manga Entertainment) of Macross II? Yeah, but not by much if we're being really honest.

The acting is comically bad but the translation is ALMOST okay. There are some really hilarious lines like, "You can schtill fight when yer drunk!" but honestly, it's not far from the spirit of the original dialogue. It's just really cheaply done, with about 5 actors.

Anyway, if you want to see a proper English dub of DYRL, Superdimensional Fortress Macross is the only way to go. It's not cut, it's got nudity and exploded heads, and while the songs are still in Japanese unsubtitled, all of the dialogue is English.
I think you can start to see how tangled the DYRL rights are even beyond the Big West vs. Tatsunoko thing.
Notice also that the Superdimensional Fortress Macross box has a copyright notice for Big West specifically, NOT Toho International. https://t.co/GQZeHQfG0m

You'll notice by the Best Film & Video logo there's also Century Group, Ltd. but I'm not sure who they are or how they're connected. Maybe Best licensed the Toho International anime film library from Century Group after they got it from Celebrity's bankruptcy or something? Dunno.

And some Best Film & Video anime was never on Celebrity because Best licensed it from somewhere else. For example, Best did cheapy re-releases of some of Carl Macek's Streamline Pictures output including the Lensman anime feature film.

Now, not all of the anime Celebrity released wound up on Best Film & Video because some of it was English dubbed and edited TV anime licensed from someone else like Saban's Macron 1 version of Goshogun & Srungle, Noozles, Adventures of the Little Koala, et cetera.

I got my copy of Superdimensional Fortress Macross from a Sam Goody/Musicland in the Sunnyvale Town Center Mall around 1998. I can place the time roughly because it was near to when the original Gundam 0079 movie trilogy was first released on VHS in English in the States.

Like Celebrity, their tapes were mostly (all?) SLP/EP tapes so worst quality you can get. However, their tapes were longer so they weren't QUITE as bad. Still bad, though. My experience is that the audio tends to be worse on Best Film & Video but the video better than Celebrity.

That brings us to Best Film & Video, who apparently got the Toho international anime catalog following Celebrity, because they re-released just about every anime movie Just For Kids did with cheaper looking graphic design but uncut and full-length. Same dubs, though. https://t.co/wl3Pu6ia17

I know that Celebrity Home Entertainment filed for bankruptcy protection in '91 but didn't go out of business until '97 but I bought Battle for Earth Station S/1, their cut version of the Baldios movie from a Suncoast in San Francisco in 2003 or 2004! So stock was still around.

I'm not sure when Clash was released on VHS originally but my box does say Artwork and Design (C) 1988 Celebrity so not before 1988. Back in those days, it was very common for the copyright date to be the year before something was actually released due to lag time. My guess: 1989 https://t.co/KymBLxDOHF
It's also interesting that the copyright for Clash is specifically Toho Interntional. https://t.co/XHSNZ0eNVc

If you look closely at the packaging, you'll see that Clash of the Bionoids has the Peregrine Film Distribution Inc. and you'll see them on other Just For Kids anime film releases, but they have a legal paper trail if you wanna go down that rabbit hole. https://t.co/M88uc39LNE

But if you cut WAY MORE than just nudity and violence you can make the tape shorter and therefore cheaper. So yes, Clash has Minmay's shower scene and Max exploding a Zentradi head at close range and Miria stomping another Zentradi's head cut, but they cut 23 minutes in total! https://t.co/1ATUyANK61
Because Just For Kids was aimed at very young children and some of the anime movies had content that would be considered inappropriate for American kids in the '80s and early '90s, they were cut.

These English dubs were the same cheapy affairs used on a lot of Toho's "international" editions of Godzilla and other kaiju movies and are distinct from the 1970s English TV dubs you often saw rerun into the late '80s in the US. Again, a lot of the same actors.

Celebrity licensed Do You Remember Love? and a ton of other anime movies (the '80s Cyborg 009 movie, the Baldios movie, Tezuka's Phoenix 2772, Dagger of Kamui, Arcada of My Youth, and more) from Toho, which had overseas distribution rights to all of these films, including DYRL.

However, I'm pretty certain most of the anime dubs were either by Omni Productions or Axis must have shared actors with Omni. You can recognize the very few actors in the Clash dub from the notorious overseas dubs of the '80s Transformers anime series. https://t.co/EL2nfPNhrL
Many Celebrity releases were quick and dirty English dubs of Japanese or Hong Kong movies, most dubbed by Frontier Enterprises in Tokyo and Axis International in Hong Kong.

Celebrity was founded by Noel C. Bloom and all (or nearly all) Just For Kids releases were hosted by his actual son, Noel Jr. I guess. He was there to tell you to get your parents' help with tracking and to hawk other Just For Kids releases. https://t.co/VOJc8tVd3e

In fact, Celebrity had several sublines, one of which was yes, softcore porn. That was called Let's Party and yes, the logo is almost the same as their Just For Kids balloon logo! https://t.co/dRvNM4F5PN

If you're not familiar with Clash, it's a EP/SLP (super low quality recording) VHS tape released by Just For Kids, the kidvid subsidiary of Celebrity Home Entertainment. Contrary to rumor, they were NOT a porn only distributor with a bizarre cartoon subline. https://t.co/xB31hjIeFe

I bought Macross in Clash of the Bionoids from a Suncoast Motion Picture Company in a mall in northeast Michigan in I want to say 1992? Maybe 1993. It was definitely after the summer I got the first issue of Viz's Macross II manga adaptation.

Enjoy my Macross VHS rip triple threat! 

First: Macross in Clash of the Bionoids, a heavily edited dubbed version of Do You Remember Love?

Next: Superdimensional Fortress Macross, the same dub but this unedited.

Last: A vintage VHS fansub of DYRL!

I also got into making glitch videos this year which was a good fit for my music:

I only wrote like 6 or 7 songs this year but most of them were with entirely different tools than I usually use like a mod tracker and using Ableton to control a vintage 1980s Roland synth/drum machine.
I went back to college and am working on a degree in Advanced Programming. I got an A+ in my first class, Java, even though I was struggling at times with the math.
